newsitem.title: USA: Emerging debt mixed, U.S. rate uncertainty cited.
newsitem.headline: Emerging debt mixed, U.S. rate uncertainty cited.

text.p: Emerging markets debt was mixed Thursday, with many issues posting modest gains in line with firmer U.S. Treasuries, market experts said.
"It's very choppy trading with very little customer flow," one trader said. "The market's just wondering where it should be and where (U.S.) Treasuries are heading."
Brady debt yield spreads widened to Treasuries for nearly every country, traders said. Argentina widened about six basis points and Brazil perhaps two or three basis points, one said.
"Most of the retail we saw today was better selling," said another trader, adding that "we saw a little bit more retail buying in Mexico."

After rising more strongly early, Mexico pars were up 3/8 at 72-1/4 bid late Thursday afternoon. The gains simply marked a rebound from Wednesday's losses rather than any fundamental improvement, traders said.
Brazil "C" bonds fell 1/4 to 76-1/4 bid. The market largely ignored news Brazilian port workers would continue their strike until paid their April wages, traders said.
"No one's focused on that for the moment -- maybe tomorrow," a trader said.
In other Latins, Argentina FRBs were up 1/2 at 92-1/2 bid, Peru PDIs were up 3/8 at 61-3/4 bid and Ecuador IEBs were unchanged at 87-3/4 bid.
Eastern Europe issues again were mixed. Russian debt suffered while Polish and Bulgarian bonds climbed.
Reversing their performance from the previous session, dollar-denominated Vnesh loans fell 3/8 to 83 bid and mark-denominated Vnesh plummeted 1-3/4 to 86-1/2 bid.
"Part of the reason Vnesh had risen as high as it did was that a proprietary position that had been short went flat and then went long," a trader explained.
"Most of that buying was done by a Street player, and that guy turned around and has been selling," he continued.
Polish debt rose strongly the day after Poland said it had bought back $1.69 billion of Bradys, mostly Discounts.

Several analysts in London and New York said the country could receive a ratings upgrade in the next several months, possibly rising from its current appraisals of Baa3 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB-minus by Standard & Poor's.
Poland Discounts were up 1/2 at 98-1/4, and PDIs were up 3/4 at 83-1/4.
